title: My Job Hunt Saga
teaser: Balancing user needs, business goals, and technical feasibility is at the heart of prioritization...
body:
Balancing user needs, business goals, and technical feasibility is at the heart of prioritization...

It has been over a year now of looking for a new job. I have learned a lot in that time, about the latest job market quirks, techniques and challenges. And I have to say, in summary, it's hard. I know, that is shockingly obvious, and in fairness, reductive, but what else can I say?

I have customized my resume, researched my target companies, leaned (lightly) on my network and have never been afraid to seriously consider any opportunity. And yet, I have applied to over 2,000 positions, gotten a handful of interviews and not been given any job offers... yet. 

I say yet because I know my heart, I am an optimist. And despite the empirical evidence to the contrary, I know this is going to happen, my finding a new job that will excite me, stimulate me, and allow me to bring my hope of making a meaningful difference to the world, in some way or fashion.

My roles in real estate and lending have been that for me. I've touched millions of lives, some very intimately, and helped them in their journey to achieve home ownership. It has been a source of pride for me to be doing something meaningful, and frankly, I don't think I could work for anything less.

All that said, and thank you if you've read this far, I intend to share my experience, musings, insights and lessons in a series of posts over the next part of my job-hunting journey. My goals:
1. Attract more attention to my profile - it's the reason I'm on LinkedIn
2. Provide a laugh or a thoughtful ponderance to anyone willing to put up with my nonsense
3. Give me a record of my journey and allow me to look back and see the progress I've made as a person and a job hunter

If all goes well, these will be the start of something great. Enjoy.

Youâ€™re a chicken. Reallyâ€”just go with me. You want to cross the road. Step off the curb, shuffle to the other side. Stats say itâ€™s a terrible idea: dangerous, low payoff, high risk. Yet you do it anyway because you have a notion. Lifeâ€”and businessâ€”isnâ€™t lived by numbers alone.

**Why Numbers Arenâ€™t Enough**
Iâ€™ve watched a lot of chickensâ€¦ and humans, by a stretch of imagination. Numbers are powerful, but they canâ€™t tell the whole story. They need a human touch: someone curious, observant, and brave enough to ask, Why is this happening? What does it really mean?

Early in my career, I could crunch spreadsheets, spot trends, calculate ROIâ€”basically a calculator on steroids. But numbers alone never answered the real questions. They could point to a problemâ€”but not why people clicked, or didnâ€™t.

**From Data to Action**
Case in point: At Wells Fargo, I presented routine reporting data. At first glance, the numbers lookedâ€¦ meh. But digging deeper, I noticed subtle patterns: some content categories were trending up, even though they were small compared to our main strategic areas. The insight? These emerging areas were bubbling with opportunity but underserved.

Instead of letting the data speak for itself (itâ€™s notoriously bad at small talk), I added commentary: explaining what the numbers meant, why they mattered, and which work should be prioritized. A few well-placed â€œwhyâ€ questions later, and the team pivoted toward high-value tasks. Suddenly, our reporting wasnâ€™t just numbersâ€”it was a playbook for smarter work. The payoff? Better resource allocation, emerging opportunities thriving, and a team aligned on what truly mattered.

**Lessons from the Chicken**

Curiosity turns raw data into insight, insight into stories, and stories into action. AI can guess patternsâ€”but it canâ€™t understand humans the way a curious, observant person can. Human insight transforms complexity into clarity, dashboards into decisions, and raw data into opportunity.

**Take the Leap**
So yes, crossing the street is risky. But with curiosity, judgment, and a bit of chicken boldness, the payoff is huge: insight, confidence, and understanding. In work, as in life, thatâ€™s where human ingenuityâ€”and a sense of humorâ€”makes all the difference.

â€œWhat if?â€

â€œWhat if compliance didnâ€™t block us â€” what would need to change?â€
â€œWhat if we tested a smaller version first?â€

I saw this play out on a project where we were debating how a lead form should be designed â€” short and simple, or multi-step and comprehensive.

We prototyped each version, tested them with a user panel, and found both had strengths depending on the marketing strategy. Turns out, sometimes the right answer really is â€œbothâ€ â€” though try telling that to your sprint timeline.

Thatâ€™s the power of â€œWhat if.â€ Itâ€™s optimism with discipline. Vision paired with validation.

Ever feel like your career is one long Google Doc full of edits, comments, and â€œfinal_final_v6â€ versions?

Youâ€™re Not Stuck, Youâ€™re in Draft Mode

Most of the time, weâ€™re just moving from one edit to the next â€” revising, annotating, rewording. The version youâ€™re working from today isnâ€™t broken; itâ€™s just the current revision of a very long document.

Every mistake, every success, every awkward paragraph youâ€™ve written in life or work â€” theyâ€™re all part of the archive. Sometimes, the work isnâ€™t to start over, but to return to a section and add better commentary. To say, â€œAh, I see what I was trying to do there â€” but letâ€™s phrase it differently now.â€ Thatâ€™s not regression. Thatâ€™s editing with experience.

Iteration doesnâ€™t mean rewriting the same thing endlessly â€” it means refining the intent. Each version captures what you knew and what you felt at the time. Thatâ€™s true in product design, in relationships, and in ourselves. Great products arenâ€™t built â€” theyâ€™re edited, over and over, until the idea is clear enough for others to read.

Sometimes a messy sentence becomes the spark for an entirely new direction. The trick is not to delete too quickly. In innovation â€” as in life â€” a strange paragraph can reveal a hidden theme worth keeping. We often discover the most powerful ideas by tracing the footnotes we almost skipped.

Even when people are performing brilliantly, itâ€™s easy for a team to lose the big picture. By providing context, showing the â€œwhyâ€ behind the work, and ensuring they always had that line-of-sight, the team began to prioritize higher-value work, align efforts, and produce smarter results. It was self-deprecating, unexpected, and perfectly timed. The room laughed, the tension broke, and I had their attention. For the next 60 minutes, I was able to hold the audience fully engaged with my content, discussions, and insights. A little humor had turned a potentially disengaged crowd into an invested one.

Another time, during a long offsite, I noticed the energy in the room was waning. Instead of plowing through the agenda, I paused and asked a playful question: â€œIf the Vatican handed out Halloween candy, what would they give to kids?â€ The room erupted with ideas. Best answers included Bit-o-Holy, Three Pontifexes, and Sacromints. Everyone laughed, everyone participated, and suddenly the atmosphere was lighter, more collaborative. A simple, shared joke had recharged the room.

Humor isnâ€™t a distraction â€” itâ€™s an accelerant. It helps teams take risks, surface insights, and stay resilient when things go sideways. Even in job hunting, Iâ€™ve found that a well-timed anecdote or playful story can make you memorable in a sea of serious faces.

So hereâ€™s the takeaway: donâ€™t underestimate the power of a chuckle. Infuse your work, your communications, and even your job search with small, human touches. Ever peered into the mirror and thought, Whoâ€™s that? For product people, that stranger isnâ€™t a crisis, itâ€™s a gift. The universe is handing you a new perspective, the kind you canâ€™t get from dashboards, decks, or yet another â€œquick sync.â€ Welcome to the funhouse.

It starts with honest self-reflection. Not the â€œdo I have spinach in my teeth?â€ kind. The deeper kind where you admit what you prefer, what you assume, and how those preferences sneak into your product decisions. The magic happens when you step outside yourself. Picture a real user, not the persona template, but someone whose day doesnâ€™t orbit your product. She frowned. â€œLocationâ€¦ like where I am now, or where I want to be when I move?â€ That tiny confusion wasnâ€™t visible in our analytics, but in that moment the distortion kicked in. Our internal jargon warped into clarity: she needed simpler language. Two words changed, and form abandonment dropped meaningfully. One small funhouse reflection, real impact.

Now that youâ€™re thinking about the unfamiliar, you have to pull yourself back into the value-add of product management. Itâ€™s time to layer in the realities of the job: feasibility, security, cost, privacy, time-to-market, brand impact. The grown-up stuff. You orchestrate competing needs into something buildable.
